course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Mathematical Methods for Physical Chemistry
course.description: This course covers mathematical and numerical methods for solving typical complex problems found in undergraduate-level physical chemistry courses. Topics include single variable integration, multivariate calculus, series and limits, ordinary and partial differential equations, determinants, matrices, vectors, and probability and statistics. For CHEM students or students with instructor's approval.
course.prerequisites: MATH 1012 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1023

reviews.author: gazelle
reviews.title: Perplexing content. Decent grade. Nice professors.
reviews.comment_content: Useful techniques for Physical Chemistry I & II are taught in this course. Examples include ODE, operators, multiple integrals, spherical coordinates, classical wave equations, Schrodinger equation, probability, and statistics. The professors will also include some examples covered in the Phy Chem courses. Basically it is an introductory version of Physical Chemistry.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both professors are passionate in teaching. Professor Huang, in particular, delivers his content from students' point of view, making us feel comfortable in his lecture. (Unlike some professors who teach from their own points of view, assuming us knowing everything.) He explains perplexing concepts steps by steps and further extend the concepts by introducing the examples covered in Phy Chem courses.

Professor Su, on the other hand, seems not effective in teaching. I was confused with his explanations on classical wave functions and felt desperate. Since then, I skipped all his lectures and self-learn by studying lecture notes and watching lecture videos. Yet, Professor Su is willing to answer our questions. I remember once upon a time, my friends and I discussed wave function problems with him after class for half an hour. After that, he also shared with us his personal life and his family. So, Professor Su must be the nicest person in the world though he is not the best teacher!
reviews.comment_grading:
My score

Assignment  20.45/20  (0.45/20 bonus point for one of the assignment)
Mid-term exam  76.5/100
Final exam  65/100
(exact mean & sd for both exams are unknown cuz the finalised versions after adjustments are not released)

Total score: 77.05/100

Final grade: B


Personally, I hate Maths very much. I survived MATH 1013 & 1014 by reciting the examples of tutorial notes and pastpaper problems. I was even below mean for the final exam for this course (I have no mood to study those perplexing stuff!!!) and I still ended up a B grade. Quite a number of classmates who are not very good at Maths could still get a B grade. For business courses, comparatively, even if you spare no effort studying, in all likelihood you will still receive a ~B grade (competition is too fierce). So 2409 is really good grade in nature.

However, be aware of the potential competitors in this course!!! There are quite a no. of ≥ year 3 students enrolled in this course to compete with us an A+. A friend of mine who got 9X/100 in both exams still couldn't pass the cut off score of A+ and was fallen into an A grade!!! So if you desire an A+, you should aim at full score for both exams and assignments.
reviews.comment_workload: In terms of content, this course is quite chur in nature. We have to learn ~16 topics in about 3 months time. The good thing is that final exam is not accumulative. You have the whole reading week to do revision. But for the midterm, the workload is really really huge because the midterm of Org Chem & the submission of Lang proposal were nearly the same period. You have almost no time for revision. So in theory, you should perform better in the final exam.

reviews.comment_content:
1. Functions of a Single Variable: Differentiation & Integration

Most contents overlap with calculus I, II, and III (vector calculus), and some contents overlap with differential equation courses. However, the difficulty is much less than typical math courses.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Haibin Su's teaching is ok. However, if you don't have any background in calculus, differential equations, or transformations, his teaching might not enough. (if you don't understand the contents after the lectures, get some study help on youtube)

But even if there's some deficiency in teaching, he and his TAs respond to questions really fast and are quite helpful.

Additional Info)
After each topic, there are additional exercises for practice. Before midterm, there were no errors in the problems, but after the midterm, the exercises covering Laplace equations and wave equations had quite some mistakes in problems and solutions so I had to correct them several times.

If you are stuck at these units, don't hesitate to contact TAs, the problems or answers might be wrong.

reviews.author: YareYaredaze
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm Contents:

1. Review of MATH1012 Contents + Integration by parts.
2. Ordinary Differential Equations(ODE)
3. Series and Limits, Euler's Formula
4. Fourier Series and Fourier Transforms
5. Function of Several Variables.

After Midterm:

6. Vectors / Operators, Line/Surface Integrals
7. Plane Polar Coordinates and Spherical
8. Separation of Variables using Laplace Equations
9. Oscillation and Wave Equations ( ODE + Separation of Variables + Fourier series)

Additional Info:
There are two challenging topics you have to spend plenty of time to understand them. Fourier series and Transforms before midterm, and Separation of Variables after midterm. Be careful!

Some contents are already taught in MATH1014, including "Integration by Parts", "Series and Limit" and "Plane Polar Coordinates". You may consider to take math1014, the overlapping contents are MUCH more difficult compared to chem2409.

reviews.author: stress+tension
reviews.title: The final is in 12 hours. I hate su haibin. I hate this course. (Extremely biased review)
reviews.comment_content: My incredible hatred for the content cannot be overstated. Do NOT take this course unless ABSOLUTELY NECESSARY. The content is barely understandable at best, and completely perplexing and utterly confusing at worst. The lecture notes are extremely poorly constructed, with frequent missing pages and vague explanations. Questions from the lecture notes, additional exercises are often contradictory and poorly explained. The only redeeming feature of this course is that the exams are typically easy, and most question types can be found in lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: I have not attended one single lecture. None. Whatsoever. However, based on his lecture notes and comments from friends, his lectures are often contradictory and confusing, with such statements as 'Please remind me to include this formula in the exam' frequently appearing. This is not helped by the fact that the lectures are at 9 in the morning. So no thank you.
reviews.comment_grading: I am writing this review the night before the final. My visceral hatred for this course and the lecture notes has compelled me to use valuable revision time to construct this review, in the hopes that those who must suffer this course can be mentally prepared.
